results.title: Benito Cereno
results.brief_description:
In 1799, the Santo Domingo is sailing to Peru, when a slave mutiny erupts on board. Only seven crew members survive, including the Captain, Benito Cereno. The leader of the mutiny, Atimbo, wants to sail back to Africa. When the ship encounters troubles, an American vessel comes to the rescue. Cereno explains that his crew has taken ill with scurvy, including the human cargo imported from Africa. The slaves are down to only a few healthy men and Cereno is awaiting the right

Credits: Director, Serge Roullet ; writer, Serge Roullet ; photography, Ricardo Arronovitch.
Cast: Ruy Guerra, Georges Selmark, Temour Diop, Jacques Mercier, John Turner, Serge Roullet, Philippe Noury.

results.title: Beni Abbes: science in the desert
results.brief_description: Beni Abbes is a Scientific Research Centre, set up in the Sahara by the French. This film shows some of he work being done, in an effort to make the desert fertile once more. Test growing of plants, the use of wind to drive pumps which draw water from below the sand, and an experimental station which aims to harness the sun’s heat to produce power are some of the activities shown.

results.title: Beneficient reprobate: ethyl alcohol, its nature and properties
results.creator_credit: Burton Holmes Films and Elmer Clifton

results.title: Benedictus
results.brief_description: A mood film which attempts to convey the passage of human life. Simple still nature photography is used to illustrate the theme, with the camera focussing and de-focussing on the subject. A lyrical flute accompaniment gives emphasis to this quiet unassuming film. No other credits available.

results.title: Beneath the veil (D)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
‘Beneath the veil’ charts British reporter Saira Shah’s terrifying journey into Afghanistan at the height of Taliban rule. After two decades of war and four years of Taliban rule, Shah’s documentary captures images of a country that has literally been blown to bits. Afghani citizens, especially women, live in a world of constant fear and terror. Legal public executions take place in front of thousands for crimes such as murder, adultery, prostitution and homosexuality. As a direct result of Taliban rule, woman and children without a ‘breadwinner’ in the family are forced to beg for food or starve. ‘Beneath the veil’ shows a country in moral meltdown, where the suffrage of humans is silenced by the paranoid demands of a fundamentalist religion in all its extremes. Contains graphic and disturbing images throughout with raw images of the daily life under the repressive regime, including public executions.

results.title: Beneath the dream
results.creator_credit: Nihon Hoso Kyokai, UNICEF and Peter Pastorelle
results.brief_description: Fuku and Lee are two young Chinese women helping underprivileged youngsters on the island of Hong Kong. One teaches the island’s many working children at a part-time school. The other runs a mobile library (supplied by UNICEF) bringing books, a chance for recreation and learning, to children living along the shores in sampans.

results.title: Beneath our feet. Parts 1-3
results.creator_credit: TV Ed Productions and Bob Scarfe
results.brief_description: The Scenery of Victoria looks at the landforms throughout the state and relates the actual location to its geological significance. “Geological history of Victoria” Very similar to Part 1, but made for year 10 science with more emphasis on the period of history each geological type fits into. “Granite” looks at the formation and coding processes that produce granite with emphasis on the seven types of rocks that are currently associated with granite.

results.title: Beneath Clouds
results.creator_credit: Autumn Films, SBS Independent, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Australian Film Commission, AFFC, Teresa-Jayne Hanlon and Ivan Sen
results.brief_description: Ivan Sen’s debut feature continues the story of one of his acclaimed short films, ‘Tears’. Two disaffected teenagers, Vaughn and Lena (played by non-professional actors Damian Pitt and Dannielle Hall), meet on the road as they flee their troubled backgrounds and head to the city.

constellations_other.name: Setting the record straight
constellations_other.description: For too long, the history of Australia was only told in mainstream films through a white lens. First Nations people have used the camera as a means of truth-telling and setting the record straight for decades.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Autumn Films, SBS Independent, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Australian Film Commission, AFFC, Teresa-Jayne Hanlon and Ivan Sen
results.description:
Ivan Sen’s debut feature continues the story of one of his acclaimed short films, ‘Tears’. Two disaffected teenagers, Vaughn and Lena (played by non-professional actors Damian Pitt and Dannielle Hall), meet on the road as they flee their troubled backgrounds and head to the city. Lena, a light-skinned Aboriginal who passes as white, is looking for the Irish father she only knows from photographs. Vaughn is on the run from a prison farm, going home to see his dying mother who long ago gave him up. He is angry and prone to violent outbursts, especially against white people. Though uncommunicative and wary of each other, the two develop an uneasy, tentative bond as their journey progresses and they encounter various Indigenous and European Australians. With extremely sparse dialogue and little character development, Sen uses visual language to convey the emotional isolation of the pair who are often framed in long shot against the open vistas of the Northern New South Wales rural landscape (shot around Moree), or in extreme close-ups. The chasm between black and white Australia and a continuing history of brutality against Indigenous Australians are underlying themes that run through the film.

Written by Ivan Sen; photography, Allan Collins; music, Alister Spence and Ivan Sen; editing, Karen Johnson.
description_for_label:

Vaughn is on the run from a prison farm, going home to see his dying mother who long ago gave him up. He is angry and prone to violent outbursts, especially against white people. Though uncommunicative and wary of each other, the two develop an uneasy, tentative bond as their journey progresses and they encounter various Indigenous and European Australians. With extremely sparse dialogue and little character development, Sen uses visual language to convey the emotional isolation of the pair who are often framed in long shot against the open vistas of the Northern New South Wales rural landscape (shot around Moree), or in extreme close-ups. The chasm between black and white Australia and a continuing history of brutality against Indigenous Australians are underlying themes that run through the film.

Written by Ivan Sen; photography, Allan Collins; music, Alister Spence and Ivan Sen; editing, Karen Johnson.
